concept.title: Example: How the collection-type and linking attributes determine links
concept.shortdesc: In this scenario, a simple map establishes basic hierarchical and relationship table links. The collection-type and linking attributes are then added to modify how links are generated.

conbody.p: The following example illustrates how linkage is defined in a DITA map:

fig.title: Simple linking example
fig.codeblock: <topicref href="A.dita" collection-type="sequence"> <topicref href="A1.dita"/> <topicref href="A2.dita"/> </topicref> <reltable> <relrow> <relcell><topicref href="A.dita"/></relcell> <relcell><topicref href="B.dita"/></relcell> </relrow> </reltable>

conbody.p: When the output is generated, the topics contain the following linkage. Sequential (next/previous) links between A1 and A2 are present because of the collection-type attribute on the parent:

dlentry.dd: Links to A1, A2 as children
Links to A as a parent
Links to A2 as next in the sequence
Links to A as a parent
Links to A1 as previous in the sequence

conbody.p: The following example illustrates how setting the linking attribute can change the default behavior:

fig.title: Linking example with the linking attribute
fig.codeblock: <topicref href="A.dita" collection-type="sequence"> <topicref href="B.dita" linking="none"/> <topicref href="A1.dita"/> <topicref href="A2.dita"/> </topicref> <reltable> <relrow> <relcell><topicref href="A.dita"/></relcell> <relcell linking="sourceonly"><topicref href="B.dita"/></relcell> </relrow> </reltable>

conbody.p: When the output is generated, the topics contain the following linkage:

dlentry.dd: Links to A1, A2 as children
Does not link to B as a child or related topic
Links to A as a parent
Links to A2 as next in the sequence
Does not link to B as previous in the sequence
Links to A as a parent
Links to A1 as previous in the sequence
Links to A as a related topic
